bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 6, 1890

div1.p: Lazear gives his mother advice on interpersonal relations. He mentions his living arrangements and the American Opera Company.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 6, 1890
div1.p:
I received your letter
of the 22nd and papers last night.
You must not let people tire you.
You do not seem to be able to shake
people off when you do not want
to be with them. You have too
much of the milk of human kindness.
But you really must learn that
it is your duty to take care of
yourself. There was no necessity
whatever for you to go to town and
run around with those wretched
girls from Brownsville and I don't
want to hear of your doing it
again.

I have been going on with my work
here as usual and nothing eventful
has occurred. I have taken a
few walks about town but have
done no real sightseeing. After I
get settled I shall take regular
walks in town on week days and
in the country on Sundays.

Our lodging is near the Meadows
which is the “common” of the town.
Hundreds of men and boys play cricket
there every evening until after nine
o'clock.

Your letter of the 28th of May has just
arrived with some papers. As to your
trouble with Jane I can only repeat
what I said before. You will have
to let those people know that you
are not at their beck and call.
It is outrageous for them to send
a harum scarum girl like that
for you to take care of. You
must just lay down the law
to them and put a stop to the
whole business. If she had had
a little spanking at the proper
time she would not need so
much taking care of now.

I am always glad to get the papers
you send. The Edinburgh papers
have very little American news.
I am sorry you did not go to
hear the Strauss concerts but
you will have a chance to hear
them with me in New York next
fall. The “Gondoliers” has been here
during the present week played
by almost the same company
as played it in New York last winter.
They now call themselves the American
Opera Company. Irving and Terry are
to read Macbeth here on the 21st
and I think I shall go and hear
them. It is not often in a lifetime
that one has a chance to hear
such performers read Macbeth in
the Heart of Mid-Llothian.

I will send you Edinburgh papers
every now & then.

I have concluded not to
change my lodging. Waring does
not interfere with me at all.
We have now two washstands
and everything. He always studies
down in the sitting room so I
have the bed-room to myself
in the evenings. He sleeps later
than I do in the morning and does
not disturb me at all.

Give my love to all at Uncle Toms and
at Mrs. Millers,
